▼►▼■► It gets to the point where I do not close my eyes the whole night.1----1Here comes a crucial twist: Cao refers to himself and his intended readership together. Note that zúxià 足下 can only be used in letters or letter-like literature. The word is never used in books to refer to the reader. In no book does the author refer to himself and the readership as a group, as a zámen 咱們 "we". Cao uses this "congenial we" and creates an almost intellectually/aesthetically conspiratorial intensity of communication which makes this document so fascinating.

1.Aversion to wind means a mild cold sensation on the skin at times or upon exposure to wind or draft. It could abate when the patient is not exposed to wind. Both aversion to wind and aversion to cold are common symptoms seen in tai yang disease. Both of them would occur regardless of the presentation of external wind or cold. Neither of them would diminish by adding extra clothing or blankets. The cause for both of them are the failure of the defensive qi to warm the body surface due to attack of wind-cold.
